tn.text: In chapter 8 wisdom is spoken of as a woman who teaches people how to be wise. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
Many verses in chapter 8 have parallelisms. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This question is used to remind the readers of something they should already know. AT: "Wisdom calls out" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

Here wisdom is imagined as a woman. If a language does not allow this kind of metaphor, other possible translations are: 1) "Is not wisdom like a woman who calls out?" 2) "Does not a woman named Wisdom call out?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: Does not Understanding raise her voice?
tn.text: Here "Understanding" means the same as "Wisdom." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: the gates at the entrance into the city
tn.text: In ancient times, cities usually had outer walls with gates in them.
This continues to refer to Wisdom, personified as a woman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
Wisdom speaks to the people in verses 4-36.

tn.ref: my voice is for the sons of mankind
tn.text: Here "voice" represents the words that are spoken. AT: "my words are for the sons of mankind" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is metonymy representing all human beings. AT: "all people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"inexperienced, immature"

The abstract word "wisdom' refers to what a wise person believes and to the way in which he acts. AT: "learn how a wise person acts" or "learn what it means to be wise" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: you must get an understanding mind
tn.text: To understand things is spoken of as if it were obtaining a mind that could understand. AT: "you must begin to understand things with your mind" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Here "lips" represents a person's mouth, which which he speaks. AT: "when I open my mouth to speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"proper" or "just"
Here "mouth" represents a person who speaks. AT: "I speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"what people should believe"

tn.ref: wickedness is disgusting to my lips
tn.text: Here "lips" represents a person who is speaking. AT: "wickedness is disgusting to me" or "saying wicked things would be disgusting to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here the abstract noun "wickedness" represents wicked speech. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Here "words" represent a message or teaching. Also, "mouth" stands for the person who is speaking. AT: "The things I teach" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"false"
"honest and clear"

tn.ref: my words are upright for those who find knowledge
tn.text: This probably means that those who find knowledge will easily understand that the speaker's words are upright. Here "words" represent a message or teaching. AT: "those who know what is right and what is wrong consider what I teach to be right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"honest"

tn.ref: Acquire my instruction rather than silver
tn.text: "You should try much harder to understand my instructions than to get silver"

tn.ref: For Wisdom is better than jewels; no treasure is equal to her
tn.text: Here Wisdom, personified as a woman, is not speaking. However, it is possible to make Wisdom the speaker here as well. AT: "For I, Wisdom, am better than jewels; no treasure is equal to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
Prudence is also represented here as a person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
"caution" or "good judgment"

The abstract ideas "knowledge" and "discrete" can be expressed in other ways. AT: "I am knowledgeable and discreet" or "I know many things, and I am careful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
being careful about what we say and do; being cautious not to cause hurt or harm to others
"wicked talk"
turned from what is right
"wise suggestions"
counsel that is given to help someone
good, reliable
Here Wisdom is spoken of as if she were insight. AT: "I have insight" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
noblemen, leading members of important families in the nation
This refers to brotherly love or love for a friend or family member. This is natural human love between friends or relatives.
with careful and continued effort

tn.ref: With me are riches and honor
tn.text: "I have riches and honor"

This explains what is meant by "riches and honor." This can be made clear with the connecting statement "therefore." AT: "therefore, I will give lasting wealth and righteousness to those who find me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_connectingwords]])
"the ability to live in a right way"
what wisdom produces or causes
the benefit or gain that wisdom causes

tn.ref: I walk in the path of righteousness
tn.text: Living the right way is spoken of as walking on the right road. AT: "I live right" or "I do what is right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: in the midst of the paths of justice
tn.text: This tells more of what is meant by "the path of righteousness." AT: "I do what is perfectly just" or "I only do what is just" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
storehouses for valuable things. Wisdom is spoken of as a woman who fills the storehouses of her followers with valuable things. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the first of his deeds then
tn.text: "I was the first of the things he created then"
"Very long ago"
The word "age" refers to a general, extended period of time.
This can be put into active form. AT: "God made me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: from the beginnings of the earth
tn.text: The idea of beginnings can be translated in a less abstract way. AT: "from when God created the earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Wisdom continues to speak. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

"Before the bases of the mountains were put into place." This can also be put into active form. AT: "Before God made the foundations of the mountains and put them into their proper places" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: I was born ... I was there
tn.text: This is wisdom speaking about herself. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
"I was alive"
To establish something is to bring into being on a stable basis. AT: "created" or "made"

tn.ref: when he drew a circle on the surface of the deep
tn.text: This refers to setting a limit to how far someone in a ship at sea can see all around himself. AT: "when he marked on the ocean's surface how far a person at sea can see in every direction" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"the ocean"
Wisdom continues to speak. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
brought into permanent being

tn.ref: when the springs in the deep became fixed
tn.text: This can be put into active form. AT: "when God fixed the springs in the deep" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The ancient Hebrews thought that the ocean got its water from springs at the bottom of the sea.

tn.ref: when he made his limit for the sea
tn.text: "when he created the shorelines for the oceans. The "limit for the sea" divided the oceans from the dry land.

tn.ref: when there was set the limit for the foundations of the dry land
tn.text: The Hebrew word for "earth" also often means "land."

tn.ref: when there was set the limit for the foundations of the dry land
tn.text: This can be put into active form. AT: "when God set the limit for the foundations of the earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is still wisdom speaking. Wisdom now says she was right next to Yahweh, implying that she was his assistant in creating the world. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
This is a person who has trained for years to make useful things very well, like furniture or houses.
"source of joy" or "reason to be glad"
This is a way to express the idea of a habitual action or of a continuous condition. AT: "continually" or "the whole time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"the whole world he created" (UDB) or "everything he created"
This refers to human beings in general. AT: "the people he brought into existence" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is to focus the attention of the children to the conclusion of this lesson.
This is still wisdom talking about herself. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
Here "my ways" represents wisdom's behavior. AT: "those who do what I teach" or "the people who follow my example" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"do not disregard" AT: "be sure to pay attention to" or "be sure to follow" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])

tn.ref: watching every day at my doors, waiting beside the posts of my doors
tn.text: These two phrases basically mean the same thing. Wisdom is described as having a home; possible meanings of "watching" are 1) a wise person waits outside wisdom's home in the morning in order to serve her, or 2) a wise person waits outside wisdom's house for her to come and teach him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: finds me ... find me ... hate me
tn.text: This is still wisdom talking about herself. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
The complete thought is, "he who fails to find me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "life" represents the person's self. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
